examples.text: One area of contention is the availability of nursery care.
Privatization of the health service remains a point of contention.
There is no contention between the two groups.

definitions.definition: a belief or an opinion that you express, especially in an argument

examples.text: It is our client's contention that the fire was an accident.
Her main contention is that staff should get better training.
There is no evidence to support her contention.

definitions.definition: a subject that causes people to disagree

examples.text: Where to go on holiday is always a bone of contention in our family.

definitions.definition: with a chance of winning something

examples.text: Only three teams are now in contention for the title.
There were three left in serious contention for the prize.
Their team is still in contention for the championship

definitions.definition: without a chance of winning something

examples.text: The Jaguars are now out of contention.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin contentio(n-), from contendere ‘strive with’, from con- ‘with’ + tendere ‘stretch, strive’.
